content.description:
Trickey climbing off the ground leads up the broken small pinnacle on the right side of the wall. Undercling your way back to the left under the roof and up the layback flakes first facing left, then facing right higher above.  Mantle onto the top of the horn and the ledges out right to attempt to stand.  Using the small roof above for counter pressure, move back left using sharp sidepulls and shitty feet to gain the larger ledges above to the anchor.

Located on the far left wall of Fat City, It is the obvious bolted line two meters right of the trad route Subduction. From the route Fat City take the cut trail west along the base of the wall for 200 meters or so to an obvious small clear cut on a boulder.   
9 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.

A fairly dirty and loose climb that you can use to access the much higher quality offwidth above, but you are probably better off doing the 5.10 sport route.  Top anchors are the same as for Menage a Trois.

If this has an actual name, let me know.

Left side of Fat city, not too far from the trail entrance/Fat City Route. Left around the corner from Menage a Trois and up a little hill. Starts with a hand crack.
Standard Rack.

The dreaded 5.9+ …. Harder than 5.10… A fairly consistent width at, you guessed it, 5 inches. This corner crack feels infinitely long as you arm bar, forearm jam, and get your knee stuck while you inch your way up passing one small roof in the middle. Small hand holds and foot holds appear often enough for some reprieve and to aid upward progress a bit. For better or for worse the rock is very grippy (read: abrasive). Really good practice as some would say.  If you are into this sort of thing, it is high quality. If this has an actual name, let me know. The obvious wide corner located above the route Menage a Trois. You must do one of three routes to access the base of this climb. Surprise, surprise, I would say a #5 is mandatory. I only had one and was able to bump it while leaving 2 #4’s and 2 #3’s where it constricted a bit. I used one .5 on a seem out right and then also slung the pillar at the start with a double length sling.

2 bolts with rap rings at the top.

This super cool crack feature that cuts the face in multiple directions and reads like it should climb like an Offwidth should, but you never really need to get out those skills. Rather it climbs like everything you wouldn't think it does, which makes it one of the must do routes at Fat City.  

Climb the obvious crack features all the way to the hand jam exits onto the top of the cliff. It's a brilliant climb, and I would recommend it to all my friends.

Note: This has been climbed clean on TR, but is waiting for its first proper lead. All but the last 5 meters have been cleaned and is good to go.  The last 5 meters are climbable, but still quite dirty and may have a loose rock or two.

Walking east from Fat City towards the bolted climb Spagooter, climb up the slope into the notch in the cliff line.  Climb a move or two of 4th class behind three pine trees onto the ledge above, and the climb is located on the east facing wall of the notch in the cliff line. 
Trad rack plus large gear needed. xtra's #4's, #5's.  The smaller (hands and smaller) gear is needed for the top 1/2 of the route.

Ménage à trois is is a fun, moderate sport route to get you up the lower buttress to the ledge above.  Start on large, flat holds and traverse left at the third bolt just a bit.  Up the ledges above to an open corner for three more bolts to the ledge above.  Climb right of the bolted headwall, and finish on the large, flat ledge above.  

Ménage à trois is located on a half height buttress on the far left side of Fat City.  Take the trail along the base of the wall almost to the end and on the outside of the buttress you will find the bolt line heading up to the ledge above.  Note, this climb is located between to trad lines (one almost shares the start, and the other is around the corner) but they all finish at the same bolted belay on the ledge 25 meters up. 
11 bolts plus the anchor

A tricky (bolt protected) start leads to super fun climbing above.  Continuous 5.9/5.10 climbing the whole way using edges, sidepulls and an occasional jam to keep the trad climber in you happy.  A good(ish) rest ledge is found 1/2 way up, where the climbing starts to get harder, and the pum clock starts.  Leaving the rest ledge, climb straight up for added difficulty, or easier climbing out right both lead to the steepening exit holds above to mantle onto the belay ledge, shake out and enjoy the view. 

This is the current, furthest route developed on the right side of Fat City. Traverse the base of the wall along the cut path for 100 meters from Fat City. It is a black and grey wall that doesn't go all the way to the top of the cliff. 
10(?) bolts to a 2 bolt anchor on a large ledge that you can't see from the ground

Easy jams, lead to a small roof to pull for the first crux.  Climb through the small roof to a good stance above, recover in the under clings and move slightly back right to the continuing crack above. Some reachy moves using the seam and face holds give way for the second crux to some bomber jugs and a jam above to clip the bolts at a large stance.

Located on the far left wall of Fat City, It is the obvious crack line two meters left of the bolted route "Continental Drift". From the route "Fat City" take the cut trail west along the base of the wall for 200 meters or so to an obvious small clear cut on a boulder.  
Standard rack.  Two bolts on top.

Start with a very short hand crack to a ledge. Then stem up the finger crack corner for a short while to another ledge. Follow the varied crack system and flakes on the near vertical face through fun and sustained movement pulling a few bulges along the way. One bolt out left about ¾ of the way up where there is no pro for a good bit. Near the top, when you reach the last finger crack section about 10 feet below the anchor, follow the wider cracks trending left and then traverse back right just a couple feet from the top.

Congrats you just earned yourself a few Timbits! After all you are in Fat City.

Note: The top anchors got a little far apart for only having rap rings, so I would suggest rappelling as opposed to lowering as it twists your rope quite a bit. Also, I did not have much extra rope with a 70m, so I am not sure a 60m would do it. It would definitely get you to the first ledge which is only about 10 ft up with a 5.8 handcrack bringing you down to solid ground.  

Left side of Fat City. Go left when you reach the base of the cliff at the route Fat City for about 200m. Timbits is about 30 ft or so right of Continental Drift.
Doubles of .1-.75 and some nuts. Some runners useful to prevent rope drag. One bolt on route. 2 bolt anchor up top with rap rings.

Fat city is located above and slightly to the east of the quarry. There is a plethora of chimney and offwidth climbing to be had in this zone, plus a few lovely hand cracks and bolted faces to keep everyone happy.

As of June 2019, there are 10+ routes in either development or have been sent with tones more potential for bolted face routes, as well as trad routes of all sizes. Some routes have bolted top anchors for convenience and cliff top protection, some currently do not.
